text:
"The city of peace welcomes the man of peace"
-- early praise for Donald Trump in the West Bank

as he sets out to do what's eluded so
many before him.
Meeting Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, the US President repeated his commitment
to peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
But that push is light on detail.

Trump's avoiding most of the thorny issues
that have stymied efforts for decades,
and isn't talking specifics:

“I am committed to trying to achieve a peace
agreement between the Israelis and the Palestinians,

and I intend to do everything I can to help
them achieve that goal.

President Abbas assures me he is ready to
work toward that goal in good faith,
and Prime Minister Netanyahu promised the same."

A short distance away - protests in support
of hundreds of hunger-striking Palestinians,
imprisoned in Israeli jails.

And that's just one of the hurdles to be negotiated
in a peace deal, on top of others like Israeli
settlement building, the status of Jerusalem, and sovereign territory for Palestinians
under a two-state solution.

Later, back in Jerusalem, Trump seemed to
acknowledge the challenges that lie ahead.

“Making peace, however, will not be easy,
we all know that.
Both sides will face tough decisions.

But with determination, compromise and the
belief that peace is possible,
Israelis and Palestinians can make a deal."

And with those ambitious words -- Trump's
Middle East visit is now over.

His next stops are in Europe -- where the
US President will meet Pope Francis and come
face to face with his NATO and G7 counterparts.
